Item.text: Let us go to the next question.
Let us go to the next question.
Hi Jordan and _user_, today we are going to use the elaboration strategy to understand informational texts.
I have heard that informational texts tend to be very challenging to read.

That is right Jordan, which is why using elaboration through questioning is so important. Informational texts are based on facts and evidence, but sometimes it is necessary to think beyond what is written in the text. By asking questions and making inferences, it is possible to understand more about what the writer is trying to tell us. To infer is to form ideas based off of your understanding of the text. Making inferences can be difficult at first, but it gets easier with practice.
I see, could you give me an example?
Item.speech: I see, _user_, I hope you will join me in reading these texts, so we can learn something as well as improving our reeding.

Item.text: Absolutely. Take a look at the medicine bottle below. The medicine bottle's label contains a warning to keep the bottle out of reach for any children. It instructs you to call the Poison Control Center if you have a problem like an overdose. The text doesn't specifically say that medicine will cause children harm - especially if too much is taken. However, you can infer this from the other instructions on the bottle.
I see, _user_, I hope you will join me in reading these texts, so we can learn something as well as improving our reading.
Item.speech: I see, _user_, I hope you will join me in reading these texts, so we can learn something as well as improving our reeding.

Item.text: Yes _user_, I hope you will also give these articles a shot! Here is the first article. The title of the story is Historic Drought Drains a Thirsty California.
That sounds like important news.
